comments.content: This may not work for some but I love the big cushie bell seat I got at walmart for $20.  I'm guessing a long road ride might bring some chafing but I used to go several hours off-road with no trouble.
Terry Bicycles, which makes women specific saddles, has a try it for 30 day and return if not satisfied guarantee...  http://www.terrybicycles.com/productregistration

I once tried a fancy bike seat that had individual swiveling butt cushions. Great idea but didn't work for me. Finally got a large cushy saddle type seat and covered it with sheepskin. Perfection! I used to ride two miles each way to and from work.

I'll second the Terry, or something with a flexible, but not squishy saddle. Even for shorter rides, something that meets your sits (sic) bones and doesn't squash anything else is ideal.  I had a gel Specialized with a cutout that wasn't ideal. I love my fancy Brooks, but those aren't the price range you're looking for.
I, for one, should like to speak in defence of concave blocks of steel.

You should be able to find a bike shop that can just measure the distance between your sits bones - they have a little gel foam thing you sit on and it makes an indentation. You don't need the full bike fit. Ultimately the best thing to do is try a few ... See More
https://m.alibaba.com/.../18258.../chopper-bike-seat.html... Look for chopper saddles
Was it two wheeler dealer?  http://bikesarefun.com/  I got my trike from them, and while it was pricier than online retailers, the customer service was/has been fantastic.

description: Eva Sclippa Friends who bike:   I need a new saddle, one that doesn't cause horrible tailbone pain after a relatively short period. (I'm currently riding on the horrible, hard, weirdly shaped saddle my bike came with, made by people who think butts are concave steel blocks.) I called a local bike shop, and they tried to talk me into doing a $200 fitting.  This seems pretty unnecessary for someone who's just riding to and from work, not doing long rides, and who just wants "reasonably comfortable," not "absolutely perfect." I've tried out Gwen's saddle, and while it's not perfect, it's doable, unlike mine. Is there some arcane bicycle knowledge I'm missing that would make my decision to skip this fitting unreasonable?

description: TR Nunley Thank you to  Julia  and  Angie  for allowing the party to happen at their house, making Jell-O Shots and Getting the Beer for the party.  Thanks to Kathy and  Sara  for collecting money and selling Jell-O Shots.   Thank you to  Crystal  and Greg; the Crystal Fussell Duo for playing mysic.  Thanks to Gwen and her wife  Eva Sclippa  for arranging the Jell-O Wrestling and setting up the pool.  Thanks to our referee for keeping it clean,  T Alesia Corley .  This year's Jell-O Wrestling Queen was Liz.  (Someone tag Liz) Thanks to all the girls and one drunk dude for wrestling.  We had great competitors and there would have been more if they had a change of clothing.  Thank you,  "B" aka  Bridge Palmer  for going out for more Beer!!!!  The ladies drank a whole Keg in 2 hours.  Lol.  The inspiration of the evening was Donna who was visiting Julia and Angie from Connecticut as well as the Wilmington Pride Youth Group.  Thank you to each and every person who came.....the grand total of donations was $550.00.  Every penny will be used to make the summer more enjoyable for LGBTQIA YOUTH.  I am sure just the thought that there is a group of wonderful women and a few guys who are already supporting them will be an amazing feeling.  The youth will decide as a group what they want to do for fun this summer.  It seems a bit self serving but I also wanted to pat myself on the back.  There was drama surrounding the event because of the Jell-O wrestling yet I continued to organize this event despite the backlash.  The wrestlers were not degraded or embarrassed.  It was good clean (sticky) fun and I even got in the ring and wrestled as well.  I would do ANYTHING for these kids and risked being beat by a woman which would have hurt my ego.  Thankful her knee started to hurt before she pinned me down and saved my ego.  She is training to be an MAA fighter so I was understandably nervous.  Also thanks to my pretend Wife for holding my goods while I wrestled.  She knows who she is! Lol.  Thank you to anyone and everyone who advertised the party.  Great fun!!! Bridge Palmer

comments.content: The only King novel that I ever have enjoyed is "Salem's lot" (and that one quite a bit, despite the male protagonist, and, well, the complete lack of female characters. :)  ).
Try NOS4A2. By his son Joe Hill. It's pretty creepy.

Might I recommend Joe Hill?  Despite being King's son (they worked together on some things, like the short story "in the tall grass"), he is more readable. His graphic novel series "locke and key"is excellent, and I have enjoyed his prose as well (though it can get a tough long).  I don't like horror in general, but Hill's writing is good enough that I enjoy his work.
Another graphic novel suggestion: "American Vampire" by Scott Synder.
Haunting of Hill House by Shirley Jackson
Kierkegaard. He will take you to levels of intelligence and clarity you didn't know existed, and he does it all with upmost sincerity and a clarity of language accessible to all!
I think King's "The Stand" was good, but I read it along time ago; the movie "The Shining" scared me witless
I'm a big fan of Practical Magic, myself
Also re: Stephen King, if you want a trippy experience, I recommend watching the movie version of the Langoliers while home sick from middle school with a fever
I also used to read Tam Lin by Pamela Dean every fall...it's a very "fall" book and a very Halloween book, at least imo...

I read it over a decade ago, but Silence of the Lambs as a book puts the movie to shame.  Additionally, I have House of Leaves on my 'to read' list; according to others, it is one of the scariest things you can read. (I know for a fact a friend of min ... See More
Misery!  .. not for Halloween  but or if you're feeling cerebral his... "On Writing" is excellent
You might find this interesting:  https://medium.com/.../the-women-of-stephen-king-the-good...
It's been a long time and I'm sure there were some problematic elements I missed, but I read the Shining as a pretty brutal takedown of toxic masculinity. I'd still recommend it!
The Devil in the White City scared me silly. Such good writing ... and reality is always scarier than fiction.
Do you watch American Horror Stories? Have you tried watching old school thrillers like Se7en?
